Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: An Investigation of Dust Dynamics on Asteroid Surfaces

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award allowed me to study the dynamics of dust particles near asteroids in Japan. I chose to conduct this research in Japan because the Japanese Hayabusa spacecraft brought samples of asteroid dust back to Earth in June 2010 (immediately prior to my arrival in Japan). Asteroids, like the Moon, are covered with a fine layer of dust. It has been hypothesized that this dust may move in response to electrostatic forces, basically levitating above the surface of the asteroid or the Moon. There were three major research questions that I addressed while in Japan: 1. Can micrometeoroid bombardment explain some of our observations of dust near the Moon’s surface? 2. Which dust particles will experience electrostatic levitation? 3. Can we use our understanding of dust motion to design better spacecraft for exploring asteroids?

 

During the Space Race, the Surveyor spacecraft observed a glow above the surface of the Moon after sunset. It was thought that this glow was due to very small (about 1/10 the width of a hair) dust particles floating above the Moon’s surface. Originally, it was hypothesized that electrostatic forces could cause dust particles to jump off the Moon’s surface (like how your hair is attracted to a balloon through static electricity). However, our research shows that it is unlikely that the electrostatic forces are strong enough for this to occur. Thus, there had to be another method of getting dust off the surface of the Moon in order to produce the Surveyor observations. The Moon and asteroids are constantly hit by micrometeoroids, which are very small rocks. When a micrometeoroid hits an airless body, some dust particles are released (like when you drop a rock into a bucket of sand). We wanted to test if dust particles released through micrometeoroid bombardment could release enough dust to produce the Surveyor observations. Unfortunately, our analysis showed that micrometeoroid bombardment did not supply enough dust, given our current assumptions. However, in the future, we may make a more accurate model and repeat the analysis.

 

Our computer simulations of dust motion on asteroids and the Moon show that sometimes dust particles “levitate” or “hover” above the surface of these bodies. Unfortunately, it is still unclear whether or not dust levitation actually occurs on these bodies because there are many approximations in our computer simulations. Whether or not dust levitation occurs is an important question because it could explain some observations of the Moon and asteroids. Additionally, levitating dust could also be dangerous for future spacecraft that may want to visit these bodies: dust could cause holes in the spacecraft, contaminate instruments, or get in the joints of moving parts. In order to better understand whether or not levitation occurs, we tried to identify which dust particles are likely to levitate. We have found that if the velocity of the particle as it leaves the surface is too small or too large, it will just fall back to the surface. Only a very narrow range of velocities (dependent on the dust particle size) results in levitation. Our work has narrowed the range of velocities that result in levitation and we continue to refine these results today.

 

The final goal of our work in Japan was to see if we could use our knowledge of dust motion to help design better spacecraft. We investigated using electrostatic forces as a sample collection method: we would try to attract dust particles to the spacecraft in order to bring them back to Earth for analysis. From our analysis, we see that this may be a feasible design, but a more detailed analysis is needed in the future. Additionally, we showed that it might be possible for very small spacecraft to launch themselves off the surface of a body by controlling their charge.
